If in the usual way a Leyden jar be 
intercalated into the circuit of Ruhm 
korff’s large induction coil, we must 
conclude from the powerfull charge of 
the jar, as proved by flashes of light, that 
within the spectral tube, the tension of electricity, before it effects its passage,
is very high. In this case the electric 
light is more bright and of a fine colour 
like that of blue steel. When analysed by
the prism, it shows the spectral lines 
of hydrogen and oxygen, mixed with other 
spectral lines, among which those of 
sodium and silicium are the brightest.
At the same time the interior surface of 
the capillary part of the tube tarnishes.
Hence we conclude that the decomposed 
glass partly conducts the current.
By means of our tubes therefore the 
theoretical conclusions of Dr. <u>Faraday<\u>:
that Electricity being merely a peculiar 
condition of ponderable matter, can not 
exist without it and can not move 
without being carried by it, are con 
firmed and supported in a striking way.*
